resources.string:
• Poison ivy vines that climb vertical surfaces, typically attaching with “hairy” aerial roots
  • The amount of hairy roots produced varies greatly from a few to a dense red mat of aerial roots
  • The vertically climbing vines put out horizontal branches displaying typical poison ivy shape “leaves-of-three”
  • When the climbing vine reaches the top of vertical surface it will extensively branch, forming a dome-like canopy

• Typically several free-standing shoots emerge from ground
  • Continue to branch and grow out
  • Shrub must be 3 feet high

• Poison ivy vines that grow along the ground
  • The vertical free standing branches/shoots are a dull brown color that attain a maximum height of no more than ~2.5 feet (often shorter)
  • The horizontal vines are red colored and can form an extensive web of interconnected red branches
This project requires the use of location! Without it, the collected data will not be helpful. Please turn on location services and try again.
